Rating: A handful of jump scares throughout. The final 10 minutes are very intense and scary.

Once the SWAT team enters the apartment, the jump scares are near constant with almost no breaks to catch your breath. Most provide some warning, but a few come out of nowhere and will startle even the most hardened of horror fans. Those who are easily scared by jump scares should steer clear.

Like the two films before it, [REC] 3: Genesis has frequent jump scares once the action starts. However, due to this film’s more comedic tone, the jump scares are far less impactful and most are minor or easily seen coming. Fans of the franchise, and even general audiences, shouldn’t have too much trouble with Genesis unless they’re easily startled.

Apocalypse is far less scary and intense then the first two films, containing the least amount of jump scares in the [REC] franchise. The ones that do appear are not very startling and some barely qualify as jump scares.
More of a mystery/suspense film than outright horror, 10 Cloverfield Lane contains a moderate number of jump scares that are enhanced by the constant tension throughout the film.
Only one minor jump scare, more of a dark comedy and heist movie than a horror movie.
A handful of relatively minor jump scares throughout the movie however one of the final scenes does contain a significant jump scare.
Though 1917 is not a horror movie, it is packed with suspense, making the otherwise minor jump scares that much more powerful.
More character driven than plot driven, 1922 is a slow-burner that doesn’t have many traditional jump scares although there are several disturbing scenes.
Some jump scares throughout, most of them not being scary enough to be major but enough to be noteworthy.

Much more of a thriller than a horror movie, with only three scenes that barely even qualify as minor jump scares. However, epileptic viewers should watch out for a scene with flashing lights at 36:50 – 37:40.
Several minor jump scares, usually involving the appearance of the infected, however most of these give a second or so of warning before they occur.
Slightly “jumpier” than 28 Days Later, one scene in particular, occurring at about the 47 minute mark, is quite intense and will scare many.
Several minor jump scares throughout, most occur between the 15 and 30 minute mark or near the end of the film.

Not a movie that focuses on horror as much as it focuses on the comedy and thriller aspects, with only one significant jump scare to watch out for. There are also a few sudden sounds, but not loud or frightening enough to even be considered minor jump scares.
The majority of the jump scares occur in a 7 minute window between the 35 and 42 minute marks. Many of the scares are accompanied by a loud sound effect in an attempt to enhance their effectiveness.

The sharks sudden appearances are responsible for the bulk of the jump scares. For the first few shark encounters we get a small amount of warning as we see the shark approach from a distance however the attacks at 48:53 and 52:43 occur with no warning and are quite startling.

In 47 Meters Down: Uncaged there are numerous jump scares in which sharks suddenly appear. After the movie holds back almost 30 minutes there are several pop-up scares. In fact, three of them are set surprisingly efficiently.

Made by the studio The Asylum, famously known for making terrible, extremely low budget movies. As such, it’s highly unlikely anyone will themselves be scared by the movie, nor the two minor jump scares.
Verbinski favors disturbing imagery over straight jump scares although there are a few minor scares scattered through the movie.

When supernatural horror and suspense meets a determined mother, out for revenge, not only is the importance of forgiveness revealed, but the subtlety of the perfectly placed jump scares will keep unsuspecting viewers on the edge of their seats throughout the entire film.
Despite its spooky sounding name, A Ghost Story is not a horror movie. There are a few bangs and bumps throughout however only a couple of moments that really qualify as jump scares.

Movie Name: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night
Rating: No real jump scares but many scenes involve a lot of tension.
A relatively large number of jump scares however none are particularly memorable. Most of the film’s scary parts occur during dream sequences.
Most of the scares in this movie are relatively low-key however the final 10 minutes do contain a couple of effective scares.

Movie Name: A Nightmare on Elm Street 2: Freddy’s Revenge
Rating: All 8 of the jumps appear with little to no tension beforehand making them only somewhat startling.

Movie Name: A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors
Rating: The film features a sizeable amount of jump scares that mostly occur within the dream sequences and involve the sudden appearance of Freddy Krueger.

Movie Name: A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master
Rating: Less jumpy than its predecessors with only a handful of minor jump scares, mostly predictable and uneffective ones.

Movie Name: A Nightmare on Elm Street 5: The Dream Child
Rating: Mostly predictable minor jump scares, with the most noteworthy one major jump scare being cheap and silly, but unexpected and loud.

A Quiet Place makes good use of the quiet/loud dynamic to deliver some effective scares. A sequence early on in the movie that begins with a monopoly game contains 4 jump scares in a short space of time and is probably the scariest part of the movie.

Part II is a bigger, scarier, taller rollercoaster packed with jump scares. Lots of creepy monster moments, and a few surprises that makes this a hold on tight to the edge of your seat horror lover extravaganza!

Several legitimately terrifying scenes – one occurs at the 35 minute mark and another just after the hour mark. The final ten minutes are also quite intense. In between these parts the movie is largely free of jump scares.
A modern giallo movie that features some gore but nothing that would be considered particularly scary by traditional standarts.
Minor scares only, mainly in the first half of the movie.
One jump scare near the end that has, reasonably, been praised for being very frightening, but not many jump scares otherwise.
A few good tension builders but no major jump scares. The jump scares that are in the movie, are quite affective.
Relies more on it’s claustrophobic atmosphere than jump scares. The most effective jump scene occurs about 75 minutes into the movie.
Most of the scares in Alien 3 are “slow” scares that audiences will generally see coming; often the music reaches a crescendo or a character reacts briefly before the scare occurs.
There are some minor jump scares in the second half however they are fairly well telegraphed.

There are a moderate amount of jump scares in Alien: Resurrection after a quiet first 30 minutes. Most coincide with the sudden appearance of the aliens and very few are particularly startling or scary.
More action focused than the original Alien movie. There are quite a few jump scares, mainly after the first 50 minutes, however none are particularly scary.
The film relies more on gore and atmosphere than jump scares. There is a decent amount of them throughout the film, but they’re all very minor.
Jump scares are a prominent feature of Alone with the middle part providing an almost constant barrage of high intensity jump scares.
Be prepared for a lot of unexpected wilderness jumps. It’s man against woman in a terrifying cat and mouse race to survive.
Only a couple of extremely minor jumps in one section of the film.
Amityville: The Awakening uses “fake outs” and dream sequences extensively to deliver the jump scares unfortunately most miss the mark mark due to a lack of suspense.
More of a mystery/thriller than horror movie, Amnesiac has only one jump scare that occurs at the 37 minute mark.
Only a few minor jump scares
Most of the scares in the early part of the movie occur during dream sequences. There is a well done and quite unexpected jump scare at the 33 minute mark just after David wakes from a dream.
Several jump scares starting from about 30 minutes into the movie however none of them are particularly scary with the exception of a moderate scare just before the 59 minute mark.
Some minor jump scares most relating to the sudden appearance of the anaconda.

Movie Name: Anacondas: The Hunt for Blood Orchid
Rating: There are some jump scares throughout the movie and some scenes might be frightening to children.
Anna (also known as Mindscape) has a few minor scares in the opening scene and a couple more in the middle stages however none of them should cause audiences much alarm.
Fairly light on jump scares for a zombie thriller, but there are two worth watching out for, one in the bathroom scene and one at the very end of the movie.
Although the overall number of jump scares is quite low, they are well placed and quite scary. Not recommended for those easily frightened.

Annabelle Come Home is surprisingly restrained during the first half, teasing jump scares but rarely following through with them. The second half is more in line with previous franchise entries delivering several high impact scares.

Many of the jump scares follow the same pattern where the soundtrack builds to a crescendo, fades to silence for several seconds and then hits with a jump scare. The formula works for the most part resulting in several scenes that will likely terrify audiences.
A handful of jump scares involving the sudden appearance of two animals. The first jump scare, which occurs half an hour in, is probably the most significant.

Despite being listed as a horror film on almost every site and advertised like a surreal mind bending sci-fi, Antebellum is, in fact, none of those things. It’s much more of a drama that sometimes has brief thriller elements with only two minor jump scares that probably will not make anyone jump.
While there are a few jump scares, they are all very minor despite not being telegraphed.

Movie Name: Antrum: The Deadliest Film Ever Made.
Rating: Unsettling and disturbing at times, but completely free of jump scares. It should also go without saying that the cursed film story was used for marketing and setting up the plot, and viewers will not actually die for watching the movie.
While there are a steady amount of jumps throughout, there aren’t any particularly jarring ones.
Apollo 18 has less jump scares than similar found footage films, nevertheless viewers should expect a few in the middle and latter stages with the most significant occuring at 26:48.
Although there are some minor jump scares in Apostle, they are not a prominent part of the movie. There are several gory scenes that may be offputting for squeamish viewers.
Despite being advertised like a slasher movie, Aquaslash only contains one 20 minute long final sequence that could be considered horror, which contains some gore but no jump scares.
A minimal number of jump scares. Especially mininal for the found footage genre.
Army of Darkness contains a lot less horror elements than the Evil Dead movies. There are minor jump scares only and most are in the first half.
Army of Darkness contains a lot less horror elements than the Evil Dead movies. There are minor jump scares only and most are in the first half.

Arrival builds significant tension leading up to Louise’s first encounter with the aliens but no jump scares are used. There are a couple of minor jump scares further into the movie but nothing will cause viewers much alarm.
Most of the jumps are found in the last third of the movie. These are quite startling but the rest of the movie contains only one arguable jump.
Fairly minor scares in the form of loud bangs and the alien creatures suddenly appearing. The two most significant scares occur about half way through the movie.
Largely free of jump scares however there are some very disturbing scenes towards the end of the movie. Not recommended for sensitive individuals.
Not heavily reliant on jump scares to convey tension and unease. Mostly minor jump scares that are well telegraphed.
Largely jump scare free however there are some particularly gruesome scenes that occur at about the one hour point.
Some moderately startling jump scares, mainly in the second half of the film.
Despite the low budget, director Blair Erickson manages to produce a tense and unsettling film with several high impact jump scares. Banshee Chapter is not recommended for those who scare easily.
Only a few jump scares that are very telegraphed.
Two very minor jump scares after the cops first enter Inceagac, but jump scare free from there onwards.

Despite being classified as a horror movie on most sites, the movie is much more focused on the romance and drama. A scene involving an animal bazaar near the start may have squeamish viewers distressed, but the rest of the movie is relatively tame.
More of a fantasy/supernatural drama than horror movie, Before I Wake isn’t overly scary although there are some significant jump scares in the second half of the movie.

Behind You is a entertaining yet flawed movie with surprisingly not a lot of jump scares. The jump scares, however are nearly all minor. There is one that is quite effective featuring a scene in a bathroom.
Some jump scares, with some effective ones, but many are predictable.
Despite the comedic tone and children’s toys, there are a few minor jump scares along the way.
No real jump scares however a scream at 44:23 and the sound of a match being lit at 1:01:45 may startle those who are using headphones or who have the volume turned up.
Some tense scenes but only one jump scare early in the movie.
The scares in Better Watch Out are minor and are almost all in the first 30 minutes.
Although there are some horror elements, the jump scares are very minimal and even easily frightened viewers should handle Bird Box with ease.
There aren’t many jump scares in Black Christmas although the first kill does feature quite an effective one.
A terrible movie with predictable genre-typical jump scares. Only a moment comes in an unexpected place.
A few minor jump scares. One major
Very minor jumps, undercut by the silly nature of the movie
After a quiet first 30 minutes, the last two thirds of the film contain a large number of jump scares although only a handful of these are truly startling.
Very low budget B-movie that does not really feel scary or tense. The second jump scare is unexpected but not really successful.
Only a handful of jump scares, most of which are very minor.
Jumpier than its predecessor with some major scares to watch out for later in the movie.
Only one notable jump scare which occurs 13 minutes into the movie.

After a quiet first 25 minutes, Blair Witch assaults viewers with near constant jump scares. Many of these are in the form of sudden loud noises and “fake out” scares (although the final 15 minutes does contain some genuinely scary moments).
Very few jump scares considering the material
Pretty obvious monster movie scares.
There are four minor jump scares, which can all be guessed before they happen.
Several jump scare thoughout. Many are minor, sound only scares.
A few shocking and suspenseful moments and less jump scares.
A Western with some horror elements, Bone Tomahawk has one or two very gory scenes towards the end however no jump scares.
A few extremely minor jump scares that do not require much, if any, caution.
Some minor jump scares, the most notable of which is the unexpected last one.
Very few minor jump scares and not many moments that could be considered scary. Contains some horror elements, but is more of a coming of age fantasy taking place during Halloween than anything.

About the same level as its predecessor. The jump scares are extremely predictable and the loud sound used in each scare is scarier than anything that happens. The only exception is a scare after 20 minutes, which really comes out of nowhere.
No jump scares

Nothing much that could be considered a proper “jump”. Most of what comes close to a jump scare lacks any build up and the loud noises often presented with the jump don’t occur at the same time which lessens their impact somewhat.
A moderate number of jump scares spread throughout the film however the comedic tone to the movie lessens their impact substantially.
One very minor jump scare, though plenty of disturbing images.
Brightburn contains many jump scares although they are quite minor with most involving sudden and quick movement from the title character.
Very few and highly telegraphed jump scares, undercut by the comedic tone of the movie.

Movie Name: Butcher, Baker, Nightmare Maker / Night Warning
Rating: A few jump scares scattered throughout, but saves most of the horror for its last third.
Contains two jump scares in the black and white 2004 footage sections in the latter half of the film.
A few attempts at jump scares but they are so slow and telegraphed that they are hardly worth mentioning.
A steady stream of minor jump scares and a few good major ones also.
Low budget horror comedy with a handful of jump scares although none are overly startling. Some gruesome scenes in the second half of the movie.
A French extremity flick with two minor jump scares early on into the movie, but is more of a disturbing thriller overall.
Cam avoids jump scares and falls closer to a psychological thriller than horror movie.
The movie fails to build tension for the few minor jump scares in this movie making them not really effective.
Only 3 very minor jump scares in Candyman. The movie focuses more on suspense and a bit of gore.
A substantial number of jump scares throughout, the most effective of which occur at the 5 minute, 58 minute, and 94 minute marks.

An infamously controversial film that some consider to be among the most disturbing of all time. There are a plethora of graphic scenes, including real animals killed on screen, however, other than that, it is not particularly scary nor does it contain any jump scares.
Some minor scares in the second half of the film.

Cargo is primarily a character-based movie that falls much closer to drama than horror. The zombies take a back seat for the most part and while there are some tense moments jump scares are largely avoided.
The horror is dreamlike and surreal, driven by its great atmosphere that, similarly to other movies of its time, does not rely on jump scares.
The only jump scare occurs during the final scene of the movie.
The alternate ending that appears on the Blu-ray edition contains the only significant jump scare.
Several jump scares however most are mild. There is one major scare at the 78 minute mark when Emily is in a closet.
Cat People is notable for containing the first recorded jump scare in film, the so-called “Lewton Bus” scene.
Despite mostly being a quiet slow-burn, there are a few jump scares throughout to watch out for.
Although it has the occasional jolt, most viewers should be able to handle the scares in Cell without too much difficulty.
Has a B-movie type feel where most of the horror feels more campy and silly than scary. No jump scares, but a fairly mild amount of gore.
One notable jump scare, but otherwise mostly a pyschological slowburn with just a few moments of horror.
No jump scares whatsoever. The movie prefers to rely on atmosphere and building tension through lingering shots and good acting.

Chernobyl Diaries struggles to maintain a scary atmosphere and most people should be able to watch without too much difficulty. Most of the jump scares are minor and occur in the second half of the movie.
Just a few jump scares, of which the first and last are worth watching out for. Also features a fair amount of gore.
Completely jump scare free until its final act. After the 50 minute mark, there is a near constant barrage of jump scare for the next 10 minutes, but eases up afterwards.

Child’s Play has an underlying comedic tone which lessens the impact of most jump scares. Often the loud sound effect accompanying each jump scare is more startling than anything that happens on screen.
The jump scares mainly occur in the second half of the movie and are not particularly frightening.
More disturbing than it is scary. The two minor jump scares should not be any trouble for most viewers.
Although somewhat dated, Children of the Corn still provides a couple of quite effective jump scares.
An intentionally campy movie that is not likely to scare any viewers. The jump scares are very minor, with only the last three being the jump scare-y in a traditional sense.
Found footage action/thriller with some minor jump scares when the creature attacks.
The majority of the jump scares in Clown occur in the last 10 minutes.

Although [i]Cocaine Bear[/i] treats its silly premise in a very tongue-in-cheek way with a rather explicit emphasis on comedy, it is still an effective creature thriller nonetheless. There are multiple sequences of drawn out suspense played completely straight, and plenty of the jump scares peppered throughout the movie pack a decent enough punch.
More of a sci-fi movie, only one minor jump scare.
Only one real jump scare, which is the second one listed below, and minimal horror as well.
Only 2 real jump scares.
Several disturbing scenes, but little to no jump scares. The first two jump scares are probably the most significant in the movie, but are not worth worrying over either way.
High number of jump scares throughout.

Coming Soon generally has pretty decent scares, and the jump scares often don’t feel like a cheap tactic. Some are not as effective as others, but they are all worth watching out for for jumpy viewers.
Scenes with horror are few and far in between, and only contain a few minor jump scares.
A large number of “half-jumps” however very few rise to the level of being truly scary or startling.
Countdown packs a large number of jump scares into its 90 minute run time. There are two major scares around the half hour mark amd three more towards the climax of the movie.
A dozen jump scares although they are usually an alligator jumping out of the water at someone.
A few extremely minor jump scares and one jump scare early on worth watching out for, but an easy watch in the second half.
A moderate number of jump scares evenly spaced throughout the movie however most are of the “fake-out” variety.
A running gag throughout the film is Aaron and Sara’s attempts to scare one another. Some viewers might find these fake-outs irritating.

The comic book theme and state-of-the-art animation (for 1982!) makes Creepshow more fun than scary. Plenty of great special effects, and the anthology-style storytelling make the film super entertaining.
A few jump scares that do the trick. But nothing that makes you unexpectedly throw your popcorn and shout.
Not many jump scares besides quick camera shots of cutting
Jump scares are not a significant component of Crimson Peak however there are some scares at the beginning and between the 55 and 65 minute mark.
Several jumps, however nearly all are clearly set up
Minor jump scares that are mostly fake-outs. The scares are more loud than they are scary so anyone not watching at a very high volume likely won’t have any trouble with them.
Only one mild jump at the start of the film.
Low jump scare, just like the first film. Also much more cheesy and less gory, hence unlikely to scare any viewers.
More atmospheric and gory than Cube 2, but doesn’t really measure up to the tension of the original. Only one minor jump scare.
A handful of minor jump scares in the second half of the film, generally coinciding with the sudden appearance of the dog.
Numerous jump scares throughout that are enhanced by loud sound effects, while most can be predicted the “fake-out” scare at 13:24 is completely out of the blue.
One big scare at the 15 minute mark in the form of an “Internet screamer” but otherwise free of jump scares.
Some minor jump scares, and several scenes featuring rapidly flashing lights throughout.
No serious jump scares or content that requires particular notice other than some flashing lights around the 35 minute mark.
Dark Shadows lacks any genuinely scary moments and is a safe option for those who dislike jump scares.
Two effective jump scares at the 30 minute and 1 hour mark, both of which occur in Sam’s room.
Several half jumps involving the sudden movement of the creatures. The final third is quite tense and there are a couple of well executed jump scares.
Dark Water has some minor scares, particularly in the second half of the movie, however it is not overly scary and should be watchable by all except the most sensitive individuals.
Atmosphere and narrative driven horror that does not make use of any real jump scares, with even the ones listed below barely even qualifying.
Jump scares are prominent throughout the movie, though a vast majority of them are predictable. Most of them involve the sudden appearence of the tooth fairy accompanied by sounds of her screaming.
More of an action/thriller than an outright horror. The jump scares in this movie are quite low key and generally involve the sudden appearance of zombies.
The opening scene contains a decent jump scare but after that scares are few and far between until the final 20 minutes where most of the action occurs.
Dead Alive (also known as Braindead) is mostly a fun film that doesn’t focus on trying to shock the audience with jump scares.
Several tense scenes however there is only one significant scare at 1:13:40 and a half-scare at 24:31.
Dead End only has one significant scare which occurs at the 67 minute mark. There are also a handful of “half scares” mainly in the first half of the movie.
Few pretty basic zombie movie jump scares.
Although the second half has more jump scenes, the first half probably has the more effective scares overall.
Dead Snow focuses more on bloodshed and gore (especially towards the end) and has a few jump scares.
A few loud jump scares are scattered throughout.

A screenlife film akin to Unfriended, Host, or The Collingswood Story. Not a ton of jump scares, but the ones that are there are well worth watching out for. Most of them come close to being screamers with sudden scary images popping up on the computer screen with loud noises.

This film doesn’t need jump scares. The special effects are groundbreaking. There is plenty of over-the-top dark comedy, an “evil” underground beauty laboratory, a mysterious immortal witch, all wrapped up in a very realistic story about the perils of ageism.
Ryuk’s early appearances provide some light jump scares however there is nothing particularly scary after the first half hour.
Surprisingly scary for a movie about the internet, with quite a few jump scares, a good amount of which are very effective.
Horror comedy with lots of gore, Deathgasm has some jump scares but the light tone of the film makes them less scary than they might otherwise have been.
Minor jump scares throughout, most are the result of the sudden appearance of a shark.
One predictable but still effective jump scare, but mostly unsettling rather than jumpy otherwise.
Some minor jump scares in the second half of the movie however, with the possible exception of the squawking bird at 1:01:26, they can be easily predicted and won’t shock the average viewer.
Numerous jump scares throughout, some of which are quite scary, not recommended for those who dislike jump scares.
Only one minor jump scare, the horror comes more from disturbing images and content
Dementia contains no jump scares although there are a handful of semi-disturbing scenes and some minor gore.
Demonic has a large number of jump scares with most occurring in the second half of the movie.
Mostly in the beginning and a few peppered in the end, but each of the jump scares are timed perfectly to drive the story forward to a compellingly sweet ending.
More of a thriller/mystery movie – no significant jump scares.
Two jump scares, the first of which, while minor, sensitive viewers may still want to watch out for.

A cross between Paranormal Activity and Rosemary’s Baby, Devil’s Due contains a moderate number of unoriginal and largely forgettable jump scares. A scene at the 45 minute mark manages to generate some tension and culminates with arguably the only effective jump scare in the film.
Devil’s Pass (also known as The Dyatlov Pass Incident) is a found footage style horror/mystery that is largely free of jump scares other than a 15 minute period towards the end of the movie.
Very few jump scares, but almost all of them are worth watching out for, granted primarily at predictable moments.
Teen thriller Dismissed doesn’t have anything close to a jump scare nor is it particularly scary.
The climax contains numerous jump scares however very few are truly memorable.
No major jump scares. In fact some of the minor jump scares are barely even worth noting. So if you are looking for a great movie without major jump scares, this is it.

Movie Name: Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness
Rating: The first half of the of the movie is a typical marvel movie, however when hitting the 20 minute mark the horror comes into full play with demons and jump scares. However, while scary, the Jump scares are fairly predictable and you easily see them coming.

There is plenty of action in the second half as the werewolves attack the soldiers and while some of these attacks come quite suddenly, only a few rise to the level of a genuine jump scare. The most significant jump scare occurs during the campfire scene that beings approximately 15 minutes into the movie.

Overall Donnie Darko is not a particularly scary movie although some might find the scenes with Frank, the six foot tall rabbit, rather frightening. In addition to the three scares listed below, a couple of scenes at 43:10 and 1:03:48 (both involving Frank) may unsettle some people (although neither is really a jump scare).

Movie Name: Don’t Be Afraid of the Dark
Rating: Relies more on atmosphere than outright jump scares however there are a few decent scares with one at 54 minutes being the most significant.
Don’t Breathe is a very tense thriller with some horror elements. Most of the scares are the result of loud noises occurring in otherwise quiet scenes.
Only minor jump scares and none of them are particularly unexpected.
Not many jump scares. Relies mostly on suspense.
Don’t Knock Twice is surprisingly heavy on atmopshere although the jump scares are fairly generic.
Lots of jump scares but always resorting to sound effects.
A psychological thriller more than a horror movie with one extremely minor jump scare.

The first hour has many sudden cuts to brief flashes of disturbing visions experienced by the lead character. All of them happen out of the blue with no warning other than a faint subtle sound 1-2 seconds in advance. They come in sequences, a few seconds apart, becoming more intense with each appearance. They happen during calm and “safe” scenes, which enhances their impact even though not all of them are very “jumpy” in the traditional sense.
A constant stream of jump scares from the 20 minute mark. Most are quite predictable and consist of various crew members being attacked by the monsters.
Dracula Untold has a handful of jump scares during two cave scenes near the beginning but is otherwise a fairly straight forward action movie.
Numerous jump scares throughout, although the “campy” feel of the movie reduces their impact somewhat. Not recommended for those who dislike jump scares.
A psychological horror movie with very few, minor jump scares.
Various loud bangs during the first half may cause some problems for viewers however there are very few true jump scares in Dreamcatcher.

Even if there is the majority of jump scares in the beginning, Dreamkatcher focuses more on slow burn. Before the last scare there are always loud moments in the movie, but none of them comes close to a classic jump scare.

Even though the title tips its hat to traditional horror, Dressed to Kill is straight up Hitchcockian noir. The plot’s two-art act mirrors Psycho to perfection. Complete with shower scene! Filmed at a time when the horror genre was diverting from traditional slasher and zombie films, director Brian De Palma touched on a taboo theme (for the times) and charged it full of sexual electricity. The magnificent score from Pino Donaggio compliments Ralf D. Bode’s cinematography to a T. Dressed To Kill is a visual scare feast of 80’s cinematic suspense horror excellence.
Eden Lake is a brutally violent horror/thriller that largely stays away from jump scares.
This type of comedy horror doesn’t require jump scares. They would spoil the storytelling.
There are numerous jump scares that occur mainly the middle part of the movie, often involving mirrors or windows.
French psycholigical revenge thriller. The jump scares are mainly the result of a masked intruder appearing several times during the film.
More of a thriller than horror movie, there are a couple of minor jumps towards the end of the movie but none of them are likely to truly scare the audience.
Jump scares are not a big part of Enter the Void. The same jump scares are shown several times.
An unsettling and at times disturbing movie, but does not contain any outright scary scenes and the two minor jump scares are not particularly startling.

Movie Name: Errementari: The Blacksmith and the Devil
Rating: While being described as a fantasy horror, Errementari focuses almost exclusively on the “fantasy” part. Some may find the movie’s imagery a little disturbing, but other than that, it should be completely safe to watch for everyone.

Although it is technically a horror movie, the “scary scenes” in Escape from Tomorrow are much more funny than they are actually scary. Viewers who are able to take it seriously might find a few scenes unsettling, but otherwise it’s more of a “watch with friends for a good laugh” type movie.
More of a thriller than horror, Escape Room is very tense at times however there are no significant jump scares.
Only some barely worth mentioning, very minor jump scares. I doubt anything in this movie will make anyone jump.

Europa Report is a found footage style sci-fi film and although there are several scenes where sudden loud bangs accompanied by camera shaking occur, they are not really significant enough to be considered jump scares.
No particular jump scares significantly stand out, but they are still a prominent trope throughout the film.

The scares in Evil Dead tend to be of the gross-out variety as there is plenty of over the top violence and gore. Even so, there are some rather startling jump scares and sensitive individuals should avoid.
Constant jump scares throughout however the film is so campy and over the top that many of the scares are more comedic than scary.

Exorcist: The Beginning makes liberal use of loud sound effects in quiet scenes in an attempt to frighten the viewer however while many of these scenes are startling, none are truly as terrifying as you might expect from a prequel to The Exoricst.
Part horror part drama movie, most of the action and jump scares in Extinction occur at the beginning and end of the film.
The aliens turn up approximately half an hour into the movie and from then on Extraterrestrial is loaded with jump scares.
Several jump scares but none of them very effective and most of them around the 35 minute mark.
Just as with most movies of its time, Eyes Without a Face contains no traditional jump scares.
The sterile settings and use of extreme lighting techniques make the somewhat predictable jump scares in False Positive a little extra super-jumpy!
