Teen cyber-thriller with no jump scares.
Intentionally cheesy and comedic, so it’s highly unlikely that any viewers would be scared by the movie. The two minor jump scares barely even qualify as jump scares.
The only moment that’s likely to jump scare a few people happens right after the 13th minute mark. Otherwise there’s only a few slightly startling moments.

Despite being a vampire thriller, “Night Teeth” almost completely lacks classic style jump scares and leans heavily into neo-noir instead. There are a few moments scattered throughout the film that might cause a minor jolt, but watching “Night Teeth” shouldn’t be a problem even for the most jumpy viewers.
No jump scares
This is a ‘Saw meets Escape Room’ movie so it doesn’t rely on jump scares. However, there are a couple, one of which I found to be very affective.
Only a few minor jump scares.

Movie Name: Nobody Sleeps in the Woods Tonight
Rating: The movie is quite heavy on jump-scares. (Un)fortunately, most of them are predictable and not very effective.
Nocturnal Animals has one unexpected and quite startling jump scare just after the half way point of the movie.
There’s only one genuine jump scare.

Noroi: The Curse has some disturbing imagery and becomes a rather unsettling experience towards the end. Noroi is not a movie that relies on jump scares however there are some sudden noises and abrupt camera cuts towards the end that may cause viewers alarm.
A few jump scares, and some scenes that may unsettle really sensitive viewers, but not a very scary watch.
A moderate number of jump scares although they tend to be concentrated in the first and last twenty minutes of the film.
Lighthearted supernatural thriller with some horror elements. There are a few minor jump scares however most are quite predictable in their execution.

The thing about Old is, you get so wrapped up in the idea of being trapped and aging (which is the metaphor of the film), it draws you into a psychological rollercoaster of continually being shocked by all the twists, while at the same time not being able to avoid contemplating your own mortality. The jump scares listed are extremely minor, but then again, in my opinion, this film doesn’t need them.
An unsettling thriller with just a single jump scare. Tonally the jump scare scene feels out of place with the rest of the movie and as a result it will likely startle unsuspecting viewers.

The jump scares in One Missed Call are fairly generic and largely predictable. The scare at 27:22 is probably the most startling (mainly due to the loud jump scare sound effect that conicides with it).
More of a romance/drama film that features vampires than a horror film, Only Lovers Left Alive contains no jump scares.
Several jumps, however nearly all are clearly set up
More of a thriller than a horror movie. Most of the jump scares involve the unexpected appearance of Esther and are quite minor.
Numerous jump scares, particularly in the middle and later parts of the movie.
Ouija: Origin of Evil has its fair share of jump scares with most occurring past the 40 minute mark.

For most of its running time, Overlord is more action than horror movie and although there are tense scenes, the jump scares are fairly minor and heavily telegraphed (the exception being the scare at 15:15 which comes out of nowhere).
There are three or four well executed jump scares in P2. The remaining scares are fairly standard and generally involve Thomas or his dog suddenly appearing near Angela.
Jump scares and jarring quick-cuts dominate this film. Those who are easily startled should avoid.

Plenty of creepy imagery (in particular the scenes with the pale man an hour in) but nothing that could really be considered a jump scare (other than some minor moments mentioned below). The bigger issue for most are the two or three scenes of brutal violence that are graphically depicted.
While most of the film is free of anything scary, there is about one third of it that classifies as horror and has a few jump scares.
Quite light on jumps until the final night where there are a couple of major scares.
The scares in the first two-thirds of the movie are minor and mostly consist of loud noises however there are three significant scares in the last 30 minutes of the movie.
Many more jump scares than the first two Paranormal Activity films. Not recommended for those who dislike jump scares.
A large number of jump scares throughout however the movie fails to capture the atmosphere of the earlier movies in the series and as a result the jumps are more startling than scary.
As to be expected by a Paranormal Activity movie, this has consistent 1st person jump scares throughout, some very effective especially towards the end.
Although Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension is packed with jump scares, most feel cheap and unoriginal and it fails to deliver the scares of some of the earlier installments in the franchise.
There is no build up tension to any of the zombie attacks (other than the scene at 1:08:40) therefore most of the jump scares lack any real impact.
Jump scares begin to ramp up from about the 20 minute mark. Most are relatively predictable however one scare at the 26 minute mark is quite well done.

Despite being more action-oriented, Peninsula has a similar amount of jump scares as its predecessor. However, most of them occur in the first act and are easily seen coming. Nothing particularly scary is shown either.
Several scenes that may disturb viewers, but free of any jump scares.
Utilizing a mix of David Lynch-esque psychological horror and some traditional slasher elements, Perfect Blue manages to create an engaging horror narrative without the use of jump scares.

A couple of scenes where Maureen is walking around an empty house provide for some suspenseful moments. During these scenes there are some thuds, creaks, and other noises however most are not loud or startling enough to be considered jump scares.
Pet has a twisted plot and some gory scenes however jump scares aren’t a feature of the film. There is one significant (although predictable) jump scare at 31:47.

The first half of Pet Sematary is full of loud jump scares (a truck roaring past is used as a jump scare on several occasions) however most of the scares are either heavily telegraphed or rather generic. The second half contains very few jump scares although there are a couple of decent jolts towards the end.

Quite a few jump scares throughout. The sudden appearances of both “Church” the cat and the ghost of Victor Pascow make up most of the scares. A scene at the 93 minute mark probably contains the biggest scare.
For a classic, Phantasm surprisingly relies heavily on the use of jump scares. Many of them are much weaker than in modern movies, but in the finale there are 1 or 2 effective moments.
There are some minor jump scares that may have been considered more major in 1985 when this movie was made. Most of them are predictable but there are still a few completely unexpected jump scares.

Director: Camilla Belle, Maritte Lee Go, Joe Sill
Rating: Though there are no major jump scares, I found the one’s that are in the movie to be quite effective. Many of the jump-scares appear very close together and are almost all within the first 40 mins of the movie.
There are no jump scares present in the movie.
Although there are quite a few jump scares, most are minor. However, if you like gore, this film is for use.
Like it’s predecessor there are plenty of jump scares and definitely a few major ones.
A zombie action film, Plant Terror has some jump scares although none are very scary due to the light-hearted, over-the-top feel the movie has.
Not a particularly “jumpy” movie however the toy clown scene just before the 100 minute mark is quite an effective scare.
A large number of jump scares however most of them miss the mark in terms of being truly scary. The clown scene at 36:30 and a scene at 58:30 are probably the only truly scary parts.
A large number of jump scares however most of them miss the mark in terms of being truly scary. The clown scene at 36:30 and a scene at 58:30 are probably the only truly scary parts.
The tone of Poltergeist II matches the original in a lot of ways, so those who have seen the first film will know what to expect. Only a handful of jump scares.

Poltergeist III is probably the most “adult” film in the trilogy thus far, not quite having the family friendly tone of the first two with more scares and jumps than its predecessors. It’s still campy and not particularly horrifying, but it isn’t quite as accessible as what came before.
One minor scare at the beginning of the movie but otherwise jump scare free.
Surprisingly few jump scares, though some very tense scenes.
Contains one jump scare near the end that is very sudden and may catch viewers off guard, but the rest is extremely minor and not worth any particular discretion.

Predator has some minor jump scares although the music generally builds to a crescendo shortly before these moments occur giving viewers some warning. The jump scares are mainly in the second half when the Predator begins to attack the team.
Moments at 1:04, 34:57, 58:07, 1:08:26, 1:23:31 may startle very sensitive viewers but aren’t significant enough to be considered true jump scares.
Some sudden gunshots in the distance or people getting shot, but these scenes aren’t really startling enough to even classify as minor jump scares, with one exception.

Pride and Prejudice and Zombies makes use of loud noises in otherwise quiet scenes to amplify the effect of the jump scares. Most of the scares are found in the first half of the film and none are likely to truly frighten viewers.
Only a few jump scares.
Only a small number of jump scares, most of which occur in the second half of the movie. One scare which occurs at the end of the movie is very effective and will startle most people.
Only one very minor jump scare near the beginning of the movie that I was on the fence about even mentioning. Gore is the only “horror” part of the movie.
Prometheus has a handful of “half jumps” but nothing that is overly scary or startling.
A couple of minor jump scares towards the end on the movie.
Psycho is filmed in a distinct 1960s style where jump scares are nor prominent at all. The 4 jump scares listed below are very minor.
A gory comedy with no jumps of concern
A lot of viewers will likely find Pulse scary, but the scariness is achieved without the use of any real jump scares.
A few jump scares but fairly telegraphed.
Numerous jump scares throughout with the most significant ones occurring towards the end of the movie.
No jump scares
Several very minor jump scares
Quirky cannibal horror movie with some elements of black humor. The four jump scares listed are very minor and unlikely to scare even the most sensitive viewers.
Raw lacks jump scares however squeamish viewers should avoid due to a couple of quite graphic cannibalism scenes.
Only a few minor jump scares.
Despite a few jump scares, most viewers shouldn’t have too many problems getting through Ready or Not.
Only a handful of jump scares in the middle and later parts of the movie.

Although it is jumpier than either Hannibal or Silence of the Lambs, Red Dragon should still be watchable by those who dislike jump scares. A scare at 78 minutes is the most significant and another at 21:32 might shock some viewers due to its sudden and unexpected nature.
Regression tries to scare through an unsettling atmosphere rather than jump scares although there are a handful of minor jolts in the middle parts of the movie.

Similarly to movies like Hereditary or The Babadook, Relic largely focuses on family drama to make the viewers uneasy rather than using more common scare tactics. There is little to nothing that could be considered a jump scare, but viewers who have the volume set high might want to watch out for some loud cuts during quiet scenes that occur at 01:46 and 13:32 as well as the scenes listed below.
This is not a horror movie, however I decided to add it to the site as there is one, completely unexpected jump scare.
Repulsion builds suspense very well and the sudden use of sound in previously quiet scenes makes for some effective scares.
More of an action movie with only a handful of minor scares.

Paul W.S Anderson has a tendency to throw 3 or 4 jump scares into a single scene. One of his favorite methods of startling the audience is to have an apparently dead creature suddenly spring back into life. Another is to add an improbably loud sound effect into a quiet scene (at one point the sound of a printer, almost comically loud, is used to execute a scare). The result of this is a movie that manages to pack almost 30 jump scares into a run time of just 1 hour 47 minutes.
Low budget mystery/thriller that is quite heavy on dialogue. Only one real jump scare at the 57 minute mark.
Low budget horror with some jump scares, however only two moments at the 32 and 59 minute marks are likely to truly scare viewers.
Cheesy jump scares inserted into non-scary scenes are a frequent occurrence in Rings. Most of these occur in the middle third of the movie from the 30 minute to one hour mark.
Like most Japanese horror movies, there is a lack of “obvious” jump scares in Ring (Ringu), instead the film relies on an unsettling atmosphere and eerie imagery to scare its audience.
Just as with Ringu 2, Ringu 0 is significantly dialed back on the horror compared to Ringu, with little to no scares at all, including jump scares.
Significantly dials back on the horror compared to its predecessor. Only one minor jump scare.
Very cheaply made TV movie with practically no jump scares other than two extremely minor ones with pretty much no impact.
There are mostly minor jump scares in this horror movie targeted to tweens.
A slow-burn horror movie that gradually builds suspense. No jump scares.
One very minor scare, however still a very tense movie
Extremely minor jump scares that should not be a problem for even the most sensitive viewers.
Unlike its predecessors in the Ring franchise, Sadako largely relies on jump scares, and as one might expect from the movie being 3D, several of them are ‘right in your face’ ones.
Same number of jump scares as Sadako 3D, but the minor jump scares are comparatively more tame. Still, not recommended for jumpy viewers.
Two jump scares that both occur towards the very end of the movie, and made quite a few people in the audience jump.
Sort of a mix between a giallo and a home invasion movie, Savage Intruder does not contain anything scary of note. The listed jump scares are extremely minor.
The scares here are generated from the terrifying nature of the traps rather than jump scares. The only significant scare occurs inside Adam’s house just after the 70 minute mark.
A couple of minor jump scares around the same level as the previous Saw sequels. Those who have stuck with the franchise thus far will likely know what to expect.
Much like the first Saw movie, Saw 2 is quite light on jump scares relying more on the disturbing nature of the traps to generate tension.
The Saw franchise focuses more on physical and emotional torture rather than jump scares and as a result there are only a few minor scares in this film.
Much like the previous Saw entries, Saw IV focuses more on gore and psychological torture rather than jump scares although there are a handful of minor jolts towards the middle of the movie.
Like previous films in the franchise, Saw V contains only a handful of minor jump scares.
Saw VI contains just two minor scares at 26 and 36 minutes.
Only very minor jump scares, or attempts at jump scares with no effect due to the silly nature of the stories.

Scary movie is foremost a comedy with the horror elements being secondary. Jump scares do exist however they are fairly tame and are often used more for comedic effect than to genuinely scare viewers.
Much like the first film, the jump scares in Scary Movie 2 are minor and played more for laughs than scares.

Movie Name: Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark
Rating: Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark is aimed at a younger audience, nevertheless there are a few significant jump scares that may be quite startling for some viewers.
Numerous minor jump scares throughout, particularly in the last 45 minutes of the movie.
The jump scares are on par with the previous movies of the franchise – about the same in quantity, and similarly mostly minor.
A large number of jump scares, generally involving the sudden appearance of Ghostface.

Numerous jump scares however few are particularly scary, many are of the false alarm variety where a friendly character surprises another. A large number of jump scares are present from around 1 hour 20 minutes onwards during the final showdown at the mansion with Ghostface.

Like previous entries in the franchise, Scream 4 is loaded with false-alarm jump scares. The car-park scene at around 45 minutes is arguably the scariest part of the film and contains the most effective jump scares.

Director: Matt Bettinelli and Olpin Tyler Gillett
Rating: Slightly less startling than its predecessor : relatively safe even for sensitive people
Pretty much the same minor jump scare repeated three times.
Nothing resembling a jump scare in this thriller that takes place almost entirely on smart phone and computer screens.
Several jumps and abrupt flash backs however none are particularly startling and those who dislike jump scares should be able to get through Secret Window without much difficulty.
There are only some loud flashes that barely even qualify as minor jump scares in the movie that should not be any trouble for most viewers.
Very heavy on atmosphere, there are a couple of very tense scenes but no actual jump scares.
Seven contains only one jump scare which will startle many viewers who are not prepared for it.
Teenage horror movie without too much horror. The very few jump scares are kept surprisingly light for a Blumhouse production.

A few jump scares, but they do not use the common loud sound effects that are more startling than the scares themselves to make the viewer jump. The jump scares are also easy to predict and often back to back.
Shaun of the Dead falls closer to the comedy end of the horror comedy spectrum and although there are some minor jump scares none of them are particularly scary.
A few tense scenes but very little for jump scares. Many very disturbing scenes.
Several jump scares, particularly in the middle part of the movie, probably not recommended for those who dislike jump scares.
Some tense and disturbing scenes that some may find upsetting, mainly during Teddy’s dreams and his visit to Ward C. Only one significant jump scare and that occurs at the 66 minute mark.
Not a large number of jump scares, however the build up to them is very effective, particularly in the birthday party scene and the pantry scene.
Relies on atmosphere more than jump scares. Several quite disturbing scenes however the actual jumps are quite minor and can generally be predicted.
The director throws numerous jump scares at the audience (particularly in the first half) and although very few of them are effective, those who dislike jump scares should probably avoid.
Silver Bullet contains a moderate amount of jump scares although most are minor and can easily be predicted. Only two scares at 1:18:42 and 1:30:56 are likely to cause much alarm.
Several very startling jump scares throughout. The lawnmower scene is one of the best jump scares in modern horror. Definitely not recommended for sensitive individuals.
Although Sinister 2 has slightly more jump scares, a lack of tension leads to a less scary film compared to the original Sinister.
Almost every jump scare is easy to predict so this is one of those horror movies for people who enjoy being shocked by some explicit gore rather than being jump-scared.
The jump scares are far between, and each one is paired with a shrill screeching sound.
Some jump scares, but the movie does not rely on them heavily.

Sleepaway Camp is not a particularly frightening movie by modern horror standards, mainly due to the campy nature of the movie. There are a handful of jump scares although they are quite tame and unlikely to startle many viewers.
Only one jump scare of any significance.
Slender Man is heavy on jump scares however most are predictable and more startling than scary.
Some jump scares mainly in the middle of the movie however the comedic tone reduces their impact.

Director Jonathan Hopkins tries to bring atmosphere to Slumber with ominous music and numerous lingering shots of hallways and dark rooms. The jump scares are quite generic although one or two might get a rise out of audiences.
Many jump scares
Only one incredibly minor jump scare. Some body horror near the end is more noteworthy to watch out for for squeamish viewers.
Some jump scares but an absence of build-up tension means they lack any real punch.

Sphere is a sci-fi mystery that takes a turn into psychological thriller territory in the second half. There are very few jump scares and even sensitive viewers should be able to handle them with ease.
The first, and possibly the last, jump scare are worth watching out for, but the rest are incredibly minor and few and far in between.
Pretty much no jump scares with only one loud flash that should not be a problem for even the most jumpy viewers.

Movie Name: Spiral: From the Book of Saw
Rating: Jumpier than one may have come to expect from the Saw franchise. As always, plenty of gore is on par for the course.
Splinter contains many partial jump scares however there is a significant scare at the 51 minute mark.
Although there are several extremely tense scenes in Split, very few of them culminate in a jump scare.

Categorized as a horror movie on some sites, but the emphasis is placed much more heavily on the coming of age and comedy aspects of the film. It is rather tense due to the anticipation that anyone could explode at any moment, but its use of jump scares is minimal.
A romantic drama with some horror elements in the second half. One minor jump scare towards the end.
While still a horror movie, Sputnik classifies more as a thriller. The first jump scare is sudden, but very minor, while the other two are more significant but occur during predictable moments.
Only two minor jump scares to watch out for.
A single jump scare early on sets the tone for straight-up horror, but the film takes a different approach for the remainder of its duration.
One noteworthy jump scare and a few minor ones, but despite having a good amount of horror elements, Starfish is a very slow and emotional movie rather than an outright scary one.

Starry Eyes has a few scenes where camera flashes combine with loud sound effects to potentially startle some viewers although none really qualify as jump scares. Some gory scenes towards the end will also be hard to watch for sensitive individuals.
Plenty of jump scares, one major.

Movie Name: Stay Out Of The F**king Attic
Rating: Two very minor jumps, however a lot of very disturbing scenes, especially one of eye trauma
A large number of minor jump scares. On most occasions these are in the form of loud noises with nothing scary actually happening on screen.
One massive jump scare 18 minutes into the movie, the remaining scares are relatively minor.

Stoker is more Thriller than Horror, but the dark undertones of the narrative, the Hitchcock-like cinematography, and the old-creaky-house-no-one-trusts-anybody vibe make for a few sit up straight moments you don’t see coming.
A gross out movie with no jump scares.
Plenty of bloodshed, but no jump scares.

Director: Anouk Whissell, François Simard, Yoann-Karl Whissell
Rating: The second half is packed with jump scares including a large number of “fake outs” where Mackey and his friends deliberately scare each other as a joke.
The final third of Sunshine shifts in tone from drama/sci-fi to more of a horror/thriller. This brings about some jump scares however they are quite minor and not overly scary.
Super 8 has a surprisingly high number of jump scares with several occurring in unpredictable places. The last 20 minutes are particularly heavy on jump scares.
Jump scares are not a major aspect of Suspiria however there are a few effective scares, generally coinciding with character’s death.
Some horrifying imagery and rather brutal scenes however the jump scares in Suspiria are almost non-existent.
Some jump scares, and a bit of bloodshed and gore.

Contains less jump scares than one might expect from a Blumhouse movie, with only three extremely minimal jump scares for the first half of the movie and three consecutive predictable ones at around the hour mark.
Incredibly minor jump scares, and likely will not scare anyone watching as most scares are done with CGI that looks pretty silly.

Director: Neil Marshall, Darren Lynn Bousman, Axelle Carolyn, Lucky McKee, Andrew Kasch, Paul Solet, John Skipp, Adam Gierasch, Jace Anderson, Mike Mendez, Ryan Schifrin, Dave Parker
Rating: Some segments are quite heavy on jump scares while others have one. The 1st (Sweet Tooth) and 8th (Friday the 31st) in particular have quite a few, while the 5th segment (Grim Grinning Ghost) has a very effective scare at the end of it.
Very light on jump scares, and the ones mostly there are predictably after the signature lines of dialogue “Talk to me” or “I let you in”.
Multiple jump scares, usually after long and tense build ups. Fairly well telegraphed but still fairly jarring for sensitive viewers.
Not for the faint of heart, Terrifier has numerous jump scares but they pale in comparison to the extreme levels of gore and depravity on display.
Teas Chainsaw 3D is more gory than jumpy although there are a couple of solid scares in the middle third.

The 9th Life of Louis Drax is predominantly a light fantasy/mystery movie however there are some scarier scenes mixed in (notably a tense scene beginning at 46 minutes which culminates with a jump scare at 48:20).
The frequent jump scares in The Abandoned (also known as The Confines) are fairly run-of-the-mill however they are often accompanied by a sharp audio cue in an attempt to enhance their effectiveness.
Nothing worth considering a jump scare  however a lot of scenes contain disturbing imagery.

Despite the presence of aliens, The Abyss is really not a scary movie. There is one tense scene about half an hour in where the crew investigate the submarine wreck and find some dead bodies and a couple of minor jump scares in the middle parts but nothing that should give the average viewer any problems.
Very minimal jump scares
The cat scare at the 30 minute mark is the only moment likely to startle audiences appreciably.
Quite high on jumps, especially from the 44 minute mark onwards. Not recommended for those who dislike jump scares.
A dreamlike, or rather, nightmarish film where most of the horror is psychological and stems from the uncomfortable subject matter.
Documentary style possession flick with a large number of jump scares.
The Autopsy of Jane Doe sustains tension throughout and although some of the jump scares are quite effective, none are particularly creative or memorable.
Only a handful of jump scares, though some are quite jarring with good build up. Two that come out of nowhere near the end of the film are the most effective.
Only a few fairly telegraphed jump scares.
The terror generated in this movie is more psychological rather than through jump scares however there are still a handful of jumpy moments, particularly around the 49 minute mark.

Movie Name: The Babadook – Original Australian Blu-Ray at 25fps
Rating: The terror generated in this movie is more psychological rather than through jump scares however there are still a handful of jumpy moments, particularly around the 49 minute mark.
The middle third of The Babysitter has some jump scares. These occur in already suspenseful scenes and therefore can be predicted to some extent.
A handful of minor jump scares and some gore, but overall shouldn’t phase most people.
Even though this version of Batman is darker and edgier than most other comic book movies, the jump scares here are few and far between, and happen with fairly traditional setups for them.
The narrated documentary style and frequent perspective changes limit the amount of tension The Bay can generate resulting in a movie that isn’t overly scary.

Takes a while for the horror to start happening, and once it does it’s more disturbing than outright scary. Photosensitive viewers may want to watch out for some scenes with flashing lights, most notably at 33:06-33:13 and 1:00:50-1:03:00.
The Belko Experiment is heavy on blood and gore but tends to avoid jump scares. The scares that are present tend to revolve around characters dying suddenly and unexpectedly.
Graphic, violent, and brutal and definitely one of the scarier horror movies out there. But even though there are numerous jump scares as well, most of them are actually quite tame.
A couple of mild scares (sudden cuts and/or loud noises)
The Blackcoat’s daughter contains no significant jump scares.
Found footage style horror movie, quite tense towards the end however there are no jump scares.
The 3 jump scares in this movie could startle some viewers, but most likely won’t.
A decent amount of jump scares throughout the movie. A very well known jump scare occurs at the 43 minute mark.
The Borderlands (aka Final Prayer) is quite dialogue heavy in the early going and it isn’t until the second half where most of the scary scenes (and jump scares) occur.
A slow-burn drama with some horror elements, no gore and only one very minor scene that could be considered a jump scare.
Some jump scares throughout although they are not as prominent as many modern horror movies, instead The Boy is more of a slow-burn relying on a dark, creepy atmosphere.
Only a few minor jump scares, however there are some very tense scenes

Compared to many other 80s slashers, The Burning creates a surprising amount of tension and executes some effective jump scares. A rather shrill sound effect is used to emphaise most of these scares which might irritate some viewers.
There are a handful of minor jump scares in the first half of The Butterfly Effect.
Poor acting and a general lack of atmosphere undermine the few potentially scary moments in The Bye Bye Man.

The sudden appearance of the title card on screen at the beginning of the movie is probably the most startling moment. There are further jump scares throughout the movie however most are quite predictable and not overly scary or startling.
Some minor jump scares
The Call does have a few minor scares with most occuring in the opening 25 minutes. The dream sequence at 12:40 and the parking garage scene at 22:37 are the most significant.
Only a few jumpscares in the latter half of the film.
SIngh uses architecture, landscapes, dungeons and everyday places to illustrate the tortured mind of a serial killer. Around every turn is an unexpected, fun and oftentimes haunting jump scare.
A tense horror movie that relies more on atmosphere and unease than jump scares. Having said that there are still a handful of jump scares throughout the movie that may startle oume viewers.
Many jump scares throughout
Very restrained for an exorcism movie, however there is one very abrupt scare.
More of a thriller and mystery movie than a horror movie, with zero jump scares.
Most of the jump scares occur in a 20 minute segment that starts around 25 minutes into the movie.
Quite gruesome but largely free of jump scares.

A “screenlife” type film preceding the more popular Unfriended and Host, making it one of the earliest examples of this kind of film. There are a few cheap jump scares that almost feel like lite-screamers, but the rest of the film is slow and subtle akin to The Blair Witch Project.
Several very frightening jump scares starting from about the 30 minute mark onwards, not recommended for sensitive individuals.

The Conjuring 2 has many more jump scares than the original and most are quite effective owing to the tension generated in the minutes preceding each scare. The first half contains the majority of the scares (although there are still 3 or 4 effective ones in the second half).

Movie Name: The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It
Rating: Like it’s predecessors, there are a large amount of jump scares, although none are quite as effective as the previous movies
Some suspenseful scenes in the final quarter however there is only one minor scare whoch occurs a few minutes before the end.
A solitary jump scare towards the end of the movie which might be quite startling for those not expecting it.
Fairly light-weight teen horror about a group of witches although it does take a darker turn towards the end. Minor jump scares only.
Several jump scares, most of which occur from the 55 minute mark onwards. Probably not recommended for those who dislike jump scares.
Extremely low budget and bad. Neither scary nor does it contain any jump scares.

After a slowish start, The Crucifixion throws a ridiculous number of jump scares at the audience including many false scares and fake-outs. Rarely are these moments genuinely scary by themselves however the sound effects that accompany them are extremely loud compared to the previously quiet scenes and this will no doubt be off-putting for many viewers.

Zombie drama The Cured starts slowly but turns into a more standard action/horror movie towards the end. There are definitely a few jumpy moments in the second half but most are half shocks (such as loud gunshots or sudden movements by the zombies) rather than fully fledged jump scares.
There are plenty of jump scares in The Curse of La Llorona and while most come in predictable spots, the sheer volume of them makes this a film for jump scare sensitive people to avoid.
Some jump scares built on suspense
Slow-burn with three jump scares that are worth watching out for, but the rest are almost entirely just sudden sounds during quiet or tense scenes.
The Dead Don’t Die eschews scares in favor of dry humor. Those expecting loads of action and gore will probably be disappointed.
Minor jump scares during the first half of the movie, which increase in intensity during the second half.
Only one real jump scare that is quite disturbing, the rest of the film focuses on atmosphere.
Found footage style horror movie aimed at teens. Many jump scares, particularly in the last 20 minutes.
Some very minor jump scares towards the end of the film. As one can easily guess, there are also a few fairly gory dentistry related kills throughout that squeamish viewers may find disturbing.
Little to no jump scares, but a fair amount of gore and disturbing scenes, just like the first film.
Once the horror starts after about 55 minutes it doesn’t let up. Definitely not recommended for those who dislike jump scares.
This film heavily relies on jump scares. Most jump scares have obvious setups.
Quite a few jump scares though most of them are somewhat predictable. Still, most are effective and not overused.
Sporadically scary but fails to generate any real tension. The Devil Inside has a few jump scares but none are particularly memorable.
Relies more on atmosphere than jump scares. A scene just before the 59 minute mark contains the only significant jump scare in the film.
Disturbing imagery and abrupt scene changes generate some minor jump scares however most viewers should be able to get through The Devil’s Candy without too many problems.
There are a handful of very mild jumps that are not worth mentioning however there are several disturbing and gory scenes.
Low level jump scares that won’t cause most viewers any issues.
Has a few small jump scares throughout, but they are generally not very effective, which the low production value doesn’t help much at all.
Jumpier than the original, with the first, fourth and last jump scares being fairly noteworthy. Quite a few scares involving people suddenly getting grabbed.
Manages to create some genuine tension at times, with a very small amount of jump scares considering its 2+ hour runtime.
Although The Endless is not a film that really lends itself to jump scares, there are a couple of quite startling moments in the middle to later parts.
Many jump scares however the campy low-budget nature of the movie diminishes their impact to some extent.

Quite a scary film due to the realistic feel the movie has. Two quite intense scenes occur at the 30-35 minute mark and around the 51 minute mark. A large part of the movie consists of courtroom scenes that are free of jump scares.
An undeniably unsettling movie however it is largely free of significant jump scares.
More focussed on character development than delivering jump scares. The Exorcist 3 does however have one of the most well known movie jump scares which occurs just after the 76 minute mark.
Some very creepy scenes however The Eye is surprisingly low on actual jump scares. One very well executed jump scare occurs at the 36 minute mark.
The Eyes of My Mother is an abstract, unsettling horror film that manages to create disturbing imagery without on-screen gore or jump scares.
Several minor jump scares. One scare towards the end of the movie in particular will startle viewers.

Director: Veronika Franz, Peter Strickland, Calvin Lee Reeder, Ashim Ahluwalia, Katrin Gebbe, Can Evrenol, Severin Fiala, Yannis Veslemes, Agnieszka Smoczyńska
Rating: The first two segments contain a couple jump scares, but all segments are more atmosphere driven overall.
Some of the deaths are quite gory and may be hard to watch for sensitive viewers however there are no major jump scares in The Final Destination.
More comedy than horror, The Final Girls isn’t particularly scary and contains only very minor jump scares that can be easily predicted.
Characters suddenly appear out of nowhere to provide for some fairly cheap jump scares in The First Purge.
A couple of minor scares towards the end of the movie but nothing significant.
The Fog contains numerous jump scares throughout. While many coincide with the fog appearing, there are a few unexpected scares as well.
Numerous jump scares, particularly in the second half however only two or three are particularly effective.

The Forever Purge manages very well to build up the suspense and then hit you with a jump scare – you know it’s coming but you just don’t know when. Though a couple of the major jumps scares , to me, were very unexpected.
The Forgotten contains some very unexpected jump scares that will likely surprise audiences.
One very frightening jump scare, and may disturb and unsettle many viewers, but still easy on the jump scares.
More emphasis on comedy, with a couple of minor jump scares that aren’t really scary.
Only a few jump scares after some tense sequences

The Funhouse combines all the expected jump scares every carnival Funhouse lover expects, then ratchets up the fear. Director Tobe Hooper invites the audience to stroll down the carnival’s midway, watch patrons play games, win stuffed animals, gorging on hotdogs, nachos, and cotton candy. Gaze upon the animatronic Fat Lady, perched atop the Funhouse, programmed to “send a message of mockery with creepy and annoying canned hoots and hollers.” This typical night at the carnival is anything but; a classic slasher-monster horror movie, inside a maze of animatronic creatures, blinding strobe lights, bleating smoke machines, heart-stopping recorded screams, and an unforgettable antagonist. Two foolish high school couples find themselves locked inside the Funhouse, navigating a maze of murderous booby traps and dead ends! “…Who will dare to face the challenge of the Funhouse? Who is mad enough to enter that world of darkness? How about you?”
A comedy horror that doesn’t take itself too seriously. There are a couple of jump scares and gore, but it’s more entertaining than scary.
A large number of jumps, mainly in the second half of the movie. Those who dislike jump scares should avoid.
Only a handful of jump scares with one very effective scare at the 50 minute mark.

Movie Name: The Girl with All the Gifts
Rating: The Girl with All the Gifts focuses on character interactions and explores themes such as identity and morality rather than following the traditional action/horror route that most zombie movies take. As a result jump scares are almost non-existent.
Some low level jump scares in the first half with 29:54 being the only really effective scare.
The jump scares are often predictable and not very startling. The only significant one to watch out for is the one 38 minutes into the movie.
Gory and disturbing however The Green Inferno not really a jump scare movie. There is one significant scare towards the end of the film at the 1 hour 35 minute mark.

After a moderate start The Grudge is packed and overloaded with jump scares. Although all of them happen in predictable situations, the sometimes deafening sound is very startling for some of the audience.
Numerous jump scares throughout however none stand out as being particularly scary.

Although there are a lot of jump scares throughout this movie, Shimizu’s sound-design is far away from the high-pitch violins of the early 2000’s horror genre. Numerous, but not deafening, far from it.

The Guest takes a dramatic tonal shift in the final twenty minutes, shifting from an action / thriller to more of a horror movie. This change is accompanied by a handful of jump scares with one at 1:24:02 being quite significant.
A large number of relatively minor jump scares with most occurring in the second half of the movie.
The Happening has only one real jump scare that occurs 1 hour 10 minutes into the movie.
Only a few jump scares, and they are so minor that they can hardly even be called jump scares. There is also a larger focus on the comedy than there is on the horror.
More of a slow paced suspense thriller than horror movie, The Harvest contains no jump scares or gory scenes.
Only one jump scare of note towards the end of the movie. A couple of earlier scenes may startle sensitive viewers.
Numerous jump scares throughout, often these are in the form of the sudden appearance of mutilated corpses. The most significant scare occurs at the 64 minute mark.

Movie Name: The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia
Rating: With a constant barrage of jump scares, The Haunting In Connecticut 2 is one of the most jump scare heavy films in existence and easily frightened individuals should probably avoid.
Despite short running time almost nothing happens in The Heretics. There are hardly any jump scares, too, although two of them are still very effectively staged.
A very disturbing slasher/horror movie that isn’t for the squeamish. In terms of actual jump scares, most are quite minor and occur mainly in the last half hour of the movie.
Although there are 11 jump scares in the movie, most are very minor. The Hitcher (1986) should not cause concern, even for the more jump scare sensitive viewers.
I wouldn’t call The Hitcher a jumpy movie but the jump scares that are evenly distributed throughout will keep you alert.
A handful of very minor jump scares in the middle of the film.
More of a slow-burn with just a few jump scares, and most of them aren’t very effective.
The House of the Devil has only a few jump scares however thanks to some excellent work by the director at building tension and suspense, they are quite effective scares.
Some very minor jump scares however even the most sensitive viewer should be able to handle them with ease.
No major jump scares, but plenty of fun frights!

Movie Name: The House with a Clock in Its Walls
Rating: The jump scares in The House with a Clock in Its Walls are fairly tame with only young children likely to find them scary.
While none of them are particularly severe, there are near constant jump scares throughout as the characters walk through various haunted houses. Sensitive viewers should avoid.
There is a steady stream of jump scares from the 35 minute mark to the end however they are fairly tame by modern standards.
Viewers who are prepared to stomach the vile plot are unlikely to be dissuaded by the handful of minor jump scares in The Human Centipede.
The Hunt lacks any serious jump scares although some sudden gory moments may startle some viewers.
Quite light on serious jump scares with one occurring at the beginning of the movie and another at the 40 minute mark.

The Innocents relies more on psychological horror than “in your face” jump scares. The scenes listed below are not necessarily jump scares in the modern sense but may startle some viewers who are invested in the story.
The Invisible Man is extremely thrifty with jump-scares and usually teases situations for minutes. This makes the few moments all the more effective.
The Invitation has only a handful of very minor scares with 4 of the 5 occurring in the final half hour of the movie.
There are no true jump scares in The Jacket however at several points in the film jarring images flash quickly across the screen which may startle some viewers.

Movie Name: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
Rating: No real jump scares although the orchestral score can be quite jarring at times.
Completely jump scare free with the exception of a sudden loud noise.
The Last Exorcism is quite heavy on dialogue and much lighter on jump scares than similar found footage films. The jump scares that do exist are mostly in the final act of the movie.

Movie Name: The Last House on the Left
Rating: Incredibly disturbing and gory however there is very little in the way of jump scares.

Movie Name: The Last Voyage Of The Demeter
Rating: Plenty of jump scares of varying severity throughout, as well as numerous drawn out scenes of suspense and tension that don’t always end with a jump scare.
A constant barrage of jump scares however the lack of build-up tension lessens their effect somewhat as the movie progresses. Not recommended for those who dislike jump scares.
The film mostly has a soothing tone rather than a scary one. There are only a few horror sequences, most notably the last 20 minutes, in which there are just a few minor jump scares.

The movie prefers to rely heavily on atmosphere and clever camera angles as the vehicle to convey its horror, however there are several minor jump scares, particularly towards the end. None of which should be especially frightful.
The Lighthouse has some disturbing imagery and an unnverving sound track but only a handful of jump sares that occur towards the climax.
The Limehouse Golem has nothing even remotely resembling a jump scare.
There are only a couple of scary scenes throughout the entire movie with the supernatural elements taking backseat to a more subdued period drama film.
The Little Things is a slow moving and dark drama movie, however there were 3 minor jump scares. All of them are sudden sounds jump scares.
An extremely depressing movie which, with one exception, has no classic jump-scares. Instead it focuses on disturbing pictures and some disturbing scenes in the last third.
Creepy atmosphere and often disturbing, but rarely any jump scares.
Out of the darkest shadows come some chillingly fun unexpected vampirish jump scares!

A massive downgrade from its predecessor. The jump scares are cheap and lazy, and the horror is nearly non-existent. Easily startled viewers may want to watch out for them, but they’re unlikely to genuinely scare anyone.
Campy horror/comedy in the style of 1970s sexploitation flicks. The Love Witch has a large amount of nudity, some minor violence and gore, but no jump scares.
The Lovebirds is a comedy, which is why no viewer expects a jump scare. But the escalation is set in motion with a really good jump scare.
Small number of jump scares, but they are worth watching out for. Squeamish viewers may also want to avoid this movie.
While the scares are easily predicted, there are still several after tense build ups.

While not well recognized for it, The McPherson Tape is actually the first found footage horror movie, and just like many early found footage horror movies it places a larger emphasis on coming off authentic than traditional scare methods like jump scares.
There are only a few jump scares at the end of the film and they come relatively soon one after the other.
The sudden appearance of the shark results in numerous jump scares although most lack any real bite.

Jarring flashbacks, loud noises in quiet scenes, and the sudden appearance of ghosts makes for a movie that is extremely heavy on jump scares. Loud sound effects and musical notes are added to many of these scares in an attempt to enhance them.
A relatively bloody slasher flick that is pretty much free from jump scares.
Only a handful of minor jump scares, all of which occur in the middle part of the movie.

Fits more into the drama genre than horror with around half the film exploring the fraught relationship between mother and daughter through flashbacks. The horror parts of The Monster do have the occasional jump scare however the film relies more on a tense, claustrophobic atmosphere to generate its chills.

Several jump scares, mostly during the segment with the married couple, some of which may catch viewers off-guard. Otherwise, the movie doesn’t take itself too seriously and is more twisted fun than it is scary.
A very unsettling movie but one with very few jump scares.
The movie has an Adventure-esque feel with quite a lot of Jump scares, but it is mostly accompanied by a loud roar or sound.

The middle section (beginning shortly after the plane crash) is quite heavy on jump scares and although few are genuinely scary, the sudden increase in volume that accompanies them will definitely startle some.

The Neighbor is more of a violent thriller than horror movie, there is only one real jump scare (at 58:49) and a couple of other scenes that, while not true jump scares, might nevertheless startle viewers.
The two jump scares listed are incredibly minor and shouldn’t pose viewers any problems. The Neon Demon does however contain some disturbing imagery and themes particularly in the second half.
There is reasonable number of jump scares that begin after the 30 minute mark however none of them are very well executed.

More of an action than a horror movie, The New Mutants contains very little to make the audience jump, with nearly no suspenseful or scary scenes. However, some very jumpy viewers may get startled a few times.
Although there is one major jump scare they are not a common thread in this movie. This slow burner relies more on mood and atmosphere.
Two minor jump scares early in the movie that are pretty much completely ineffective.
A slow-burn mystery film with some horror elements. The Ninth Gate contains no jump scares.
There are just three small jump scares in The Number 23 with the first at 28:37 being the only one likely to truly startle viewers.
Like other entries in The Conjuring franchise, The Nun is heavy on the jump scares particularly in the second half although most of the significant scares are revealed in the trailers.
While there are many jump scares, none of them are particularly effective.

The Omen relies much more on the mood and atmosphere of the movie rather than jump scares. But make no mistake, there are a few minor ones throughout and one major one that may temporarily lift you out of your seat!
Although there are several iconic horror scenes, there is only one real jump scare and it occurs towards the end of the movie.
A Hitchcockian suspense-thriller that doesn’t resort to jump scares.
Most of the jump scares in The Open House involve characters unexpectedly bumping into other characters or loud bangs and thumps occurring in quiet scenes.
Relies on atmosphere rather than jump scares however the bus scene that occurs 45 minutes in does contain a significant and somewhat unexpected jump scare.

Movie Name: The Other Side of the Door
Rating: Although heavy on jump scares, The Other Side of the Door fails to create any real terror and seasoned horror viewers will find most of the scares quite predictable.
A very effective horror movie that is light on jump scares.

The jumps in The Pact are not particularly scary by themselves however the film does an excellent job at building a tense atmosphere and some will find the scenes of Annie walking around a dark house alone quite hard to watch.

There are several jump scares although the film is too campy to really frighten audiences. One scene that begins at the 72 minute mark does manage to build some suspense and it ends with a well executed jump scare.
The Perfection has virtually no jump scares although there are some very gory and disturbing scenes.

Movie Name: The Perfume of the Lady in Black
Rating: Although few in number, the jump scares are worth watching out for.
Consistently effective, but not quite major jump scares throughout.
A few minor jumps in regards to the alligator after some tense scenes.
Not overly jumpy although there are a couple of decent scares in the middle to later parts of the movie.

The Possession of Michael King is filled with jump scares that are often accompanied by bursts of high pitched static and other sound effects that are much louder than the rest of the film. Listening at a loud volume or through headphones is not advised.

Despite a low amount of jump scares, contains many sudden cuts that occur on a near minutely basis which might require sensitive viewers to keep volume relatively low, and is deeply unsettling. Not recommended for the faint of heart.
A handful of very minor jump scares only. The Predator is more in the vein of an action comedy than a horror movie and there is a definite lack of real tension or scary scenes.
Many jump scares througout the movie, probably the most significant one at the 75 minute mark. Feint hearted people should avoid this movie
Several jump scares throughout however The Purge lacks the required build up tension and atmosphere to make any of them memorable.
The Purge: Anarchy is more of an action/thriller than outright horror movie. There are many “cheap” jump scares that are more startling than truly scary.

Much like the second movie in the franchise, The Purge: Election Year plays out more like an action/thriller than horror movie. The jump scares are less pronounced than in either of the previous movies and occur mainly in the middle third of the film.
Gradually increases in its jumpiness as it goes on. Nothing too significant to watch out for in the first hour, but has a bunch of jump scares in succession afterwards where caution is advised.

The scares in The Quiet Ones generally revolve around loud bangs and sudden movements during quiet scenes and while some effort is made to build up to these moments, none of the scares are particularly memorable.
Not quite horror in the sense that it is scary, but more so in that it’s incredibly bleak, strange and artsy. No jump scares.
Several jump scares, though none are overly effective.

Movie Name: The Return of the Living Dead
Rating: Only one real jump, quite a few others that could be very questionable but hardly scary.
Several creepy scenes however there is only one jump scare of note which occurs 15 minutes into the movie.
Contains slightly more jump scares than The Ring with most occurring in the first hour of the movie.
Generally known for being a less scary remake of Ringu. Only contains three extremely minor jump scares that should not be a problem for any viewers.
The Rite contains a few minor jump scares mainly in the second half.

The Ritual definitely has frequent jump scares starting from about the 20 minute mark. Very few scares will catch viewers off guard and on most occasions the sound effects are more startling than anything happening on screen.
Some minor jump scares at the start and towards the end, but even during a theatrical viewing with very loud sound they were not particularly startling.
No major jump scares, more of a slow burn with sudden shocking twists.
Found footage style horror movie with only a couple of very minor jump scares however there are some disturbing scenes in the final 15 minutes.
no jump scares

Some tension generated through dark music and ominous underwater shots in the early parts of the film. The actual jump scares however are few and far between and all but the most nervous viewers will be able to watch The Shallows without much difficulty.
The Shape of Water has just two small jump scares in the opening half hour of the movie.
High amounts of jump scares throughout, though none are particularly scary.
Virtually no jump scares.
No jump scares but terrifying nevertheless.
More of a supernatural drama than an outright horror movie. There are a couple of startling scenes at the 76 and 81 minute mark.
A few significant scares in the first half of the movie, generally involving “false-alarms” where a harmless character appears suddenly.

There are a few minor jump scares mainly in the second half however the snowman element simply isn’t scary and the incoherent plot and sloppy editing get in the way of creating any genuinely suspenseful moments.
One very minor jump scare
The movie fails at being scary in any sort of way, and there’s no jump scares to worry about.
Mostly loud noises and screams. While they don’t ruin the film’s tension, they certainly come out of nowhere.

From the 20 minute mark onwards this movie is full of jump scares. Many of these are in the form of loud banging noises however there are also many significant jump scares. Easily frightened people should probably avoid.

Perhaps somewhat surprisingly, The Strangers: Prey at Night, only has two really major scares and one of these will be familiar to those who have seen the trailer. Almost all the jump scares occur during a half hour section in the middle of the film.

A couple of deaths happen out of the blue, and one of them can count as a “major” jump scare due to how loud and effective it is during an otherwise calm scene. Still, The Suicide Squad is an action movie that isn’t trying hard to be a “thriller”, and apart from those couple of moments, it should be a very comfortable watch even for the most jumpy viewers. In line with the official promotional materials which focus on the claim that “Anyone can die”, the descriptions below don’t mention any characters by name.
Thriller from FrightFest that can get very tense and morbid, but is not really a horror film. No jump scares.
A large number of “half jumps” consisting of sudden loud noises occur throughout the film. Some more significant scares occur at 27:05, 32:36, 1:14:49, and in the cave scenes towards the end.
This film induces horror mainly through tension. There are only a few jumps which aren’t very frightful in comparison to this intensity that the film captures.
Quite a few predictable jumpscares are positioned throughout the film although only one at the 1 hour 20 min mark stands out.
Not very many jump scares, but a few extremely effective ones.

Movie Name: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning
Rating: Jump scares are mixed with scenes of torture and gore. None of the jump scares are particularly effective on their own however they are accompanied by a loud sound effect that may make them quite startling for some viewers.
Some jump scares, mainly in the last 30 minutes, however the remake of The Thing is much less “jumpy” than most modern horror movies.
Tense and claustrophobic, The Thing contains a handful of solid jump scares.
The Town That Dreaded Sundown is not overly reliant on jump scares although one at 20:39, and another at 1:07:52 are well executed.
A couple of minor jump scares in the second half of the movie (the low rumbling sound effect is arguably more startling than anything we see on screen).

Low budget Australian horror that mixes a documentary style retelling with found footage. There are a handful of jump scares in the second half of the movie with the ones at 56:51, 1:09:21, and 1:13:57 being the most significant.

An exceptionally bad horror movie with lame jump scares that don’t even build up a spark of tension. The majority of the scares come within a few minutes, whereas one of them is set really nasty and will get every viewer off guard.

The Unborn is fairly heavy on jump scares although most are telegraphed. There is some attempts to create suspense prior to several of the jump scares. The bathroom scene about quarter of an hour into the movie is a good example of this with about 90 seconds of build up culminating in a well executed scare.
Plenty of minor jump scares. The 2 major ones were unexpected for me. Most people won’t find the jump scares too scary.
Three or four scary scenes that contain most of the “jumpy” moments. The scenes that occur at 18 and 52 minutes marks contain the most significant scares.
A dialogue heavy movie with zero jump scares, as well as little to no tense or scary moments.
Although The Veil contains mostly predictable scares, there are two very sudden and startling jump scares in the first half of the movie.
Jump scares mostly occur during the second half of the movie, however none are particularly startling.
Heavy on mystery and atmosphere but very few jump scares.
The Visit is quite low on jump scares however the final 30 minutes does contain a few shocks along with some creepy and disturbing scenes.
Only a few minor jump scares, with the horror usually reserved for only a few key moments throughout.
Most jump scares in this movie are pretty tame and predictable.
A couple of scenes may startle sensitive viewers however there are no significant jump scares in The Voices.
The Void is a throwback to the style of 80s body horror films and while definitely creepy, it does not contain any significant jump scares.
The Wailing is a South Korean horror/mystery film that doesn’t resort to cheap jump scares, rather a slow building unease as the events unfold.

A large number of jump scares particularly in the second half of the movie, generally the result of the sudden appearance of a disfigured ghost woman. While some of these are startling initially, the predictable nature of the scares soon lessens their impact.
Only minor jump scares in this kid-friendly horror movie, but they did a good job by keeping a creepy vibe throughout.
Some very minor scares towards the end as the film builds towards it’s shocking conclusion.
There are a few minor jump scares
Very few jump scares with one at the 40 minute mark and three minor ones towards the end of the film.
A few very long and tense scenes but the jumps mainly come from lights flashing or quick scene changes.

The sudden appearance of the werewolf in various scenes provides the basis for most of the jump scares. Loud sound effects play during these moments in an attempt to amplify these scares. A “one-two” punch is used on more than one occasion where a small jump scare is followed by a much larger one a few seconds later.
Several jump scares, many consist of screaming faces flashing up on screen. Probably best to avoid if you dislike jump scares.

Movie Name: The Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death
Rating: The majority of the jumps occur after the first hour of the film, several of which are quite effective.
This Hitchcockian-style thriller pay homage to Rear Window, and has the perfectly planted, unexpected jump scares which keep you guessing whodunit until the final seconds of the film’s climax.
Several fake out scares near the beginning with only one real good scare, nothing much for the second half.

Them (also known as Ils), is an extremely tense French horror/thriller in a similar vein to The Strangers. There is a large amount of jump scares for such a short film with the opening scene, a scene at 30 minutes, and the attic scene at 45 minutes providing most of the scares.
Thesis (also known as Tesis) is largely jump scare free although there are a couple of minor ones towards the end of the movie.
Indie psychological thriller with very little in the way of jump scares.
Just a few minor, yet effective jump scares.

Flashing images, high pitched noises and abrupt cuts are used throughout and often interrupt the flow of the movie. As a result none of the scares listed below are particularly effective at scaring the audience due to a lack of build up tension.
The jump scares only happen when Gorr is present, and you can see him coming. The scares are ended with a comedic element to switch the tone from horror to something more light-hearted.
Isolation and Desperation at every turn. The sharply tuned and erratic music complements every unexpected and surprisingly effective jump scare.
Timecrimes (also known as Los cronocrímenes) has some tense scenes in the first act but only a couple of fairly inconsequential jump scares.

A jump scare very early on that’s unexpected, but otherwise Tokyo Gore Police is campy and over-the-top, hence not as scary as much as it is entertaining. It should also go without saying, of course, that the movie is not recommended for viewers who do not like gore, and a scene taking place in a metro train at the 33 minute mark has flashing lights that photosensitive viewers may want to watch out for as well.
A couple of jump scares, but all minor ones. That, along with the campy feel and PG rating, should make Tourist Trap an accessible watch for most viewers.
Tragedy Girls is foremost a comedy and while there is some low level jump scares they occur in predictable places and won’t be startling for most viewers.
A couple of minor jump scares however nothing overly startling or scary.

Trash Fire contains a mix of the comedy, horror, and romance genres. While there are no jump scares there are several abrupt flashbacks that may startle sensitive viewers, these occur at 4:54, 18:54, 27:38, and 1:10:28.

Several instances of the creatures coming out of the ground could be construed as jump scares however the predictability of these moments, and the overall campy nature of the film makes most of these scenes easy to handle.
More of a mystery/thriller than horror movie, Triangle manages to tell a compelling and unique story while largely avoiding jump scares.
Some minor jump scares throughout.
The few jump scares in Truth or Dare occur in obvious places and are fairly uninspired. Only two moments at 39:41 and 1:01:48 are likely to truly startle audiences.

Tucker and Dale vs. Evil falls much closer to a comedy than horror movie despite some rather gory scenes. There are a few half jumps, particularly near the beginning but nothing that will truly frighten viewers.
Horror/comedy that is more absurd than disturbing or scary; Tusk contains no real jump scares.
After a slow start, Under The Shadow has a large number of jump scares in the second half. The window scene at 48:19 in particular is extremely effective and will likely cause most viewers to jump.
Starts and ends with 15 minutes of jump scare free periods, but has quite a large number of jump scares in between. While they mostly occur at predictable moments, caution is still advised.

The entire movie takes place on a laptop screen which limits the ability of the jump scares to be truly effective. Still, there are a handful of well placed jump scares, the most notable occurring at the 47 minute mark.
There are very few actual jump scares in Unfriended: The Dark Web, although some sudden loud noises may startle sensitive viewers.
There are a couple of mildly startling scenes in Unsane but nothing that really qualifies as a jump scare.
Numerous jump scares throughout, some of which are quite effective. Not recommended for those who dislike jump scares.
A small handful of jump scares, but due to a lack of tension or atmosphere throughout the movie, none are particularly effective.
While there are a couple jump scares throughout, most aren’t particularly effective. Less jumpy than Urban Legend (1998), its predecessor, overall.

There are jump scares in Us although they are minor and far less intrusive than one might expect from a modern home invasion horror movie. Most of the jump scares occur in the middle of the movie between the 40 and 90 minute mark.

The director uses abrupt zooms and other camera tricks in order to increase the effectiveness of some of the scares. Many of the jump scares are accompanied by particularly gory imagery which might disturb some viewers.

Director: Matt Bettinelli-Olpin, David Bruckner, Tyler Gillett, Justin Martinez, Glenn McQuaid, Radio Silence, Joe Swanberg, Chad Villella, Ti West, Adam Wingard
Rating: Not too many jump scares, but some are quite effective. The scares that feature in the segment “The Sick Thing That Happened to Emily When She Was Younger” stand out the most.

Director: Simon Barrett, Jason Eisener, Gareth Evans, Gregg Hale, Eduardo Sánchez, Timo Tjahjanto, Adam Wingard
Rating: Jump scares are present throughout the film but are most prevalent in the “Phase I Clinical Trials” segment.

Director: Simon Barrett, Chloe Okuno, Ryan Prows, Jennifer Reeder, Timo Tjahjanto
Rating: Several jump scares scattered throughout the segments, though none are particularly unsettling.

Director: Justin Benson, Gregg Bishop, Marcel Sarmiento, Aaron Moorhead, Nacho Vigalondo
Rating: One or two jump scares for each segment of the anthology, but none of the segments are particularly frightening compared to its two predecessors in the V/H/S franchise.
More of a thriller than a horror movie, the jump scares in Vacancy are relatively minor.
Much lower in production value compared to the first, and largely devoid of any tension as well, with only a few minor jump scares that don’t really have any impact.
Even more low in production value than both of its predecessors, with little to no tension or any content that could be called scary.

Van Helsing is an unintentionally funny adventure/action film with predictable jump scares. Not one of them will catch you off guard. In most moments the audio cue comes before the shocks, so they are ineffective.
Velvet Buzzsaw has a few tame jump scares sprinkled throughout but is substantially less scary than most modern horror movies.
This is more of a sci-fi action superhero movie but it has some horror moments just a couple of jump scares.
